abstracts.cdata!:
During the past several decades, the
            demands placed on Mexico's water resources increased
            dramatically largely due to rapid population growth.
            Although these regions came to account for close to 90
            percent of gross domestic product and over three-quarters of
            the population. They received less than a third of total
            runoff. This made these areas extremely vulnerable to major
            surface and groundwater shortages, with profound
            implications for further economic development. In the early
            1990s, the Government of Mexico determined that a major
            effort needed to be made to improve water management,
            conservation, and intersectoral allocation of water
            resources. A new national water law was approved in 1992 and
            its regulations were passed in 1994. The law sets out broad
            mandates for the development and implementation of plans and
            policies related to water resources management and assigns
            the national water commission, created in 1989, the
            responsibility to carry them out. The national water plan
            1995-2000 aimed at ensuring adequate water to satisfy the
            needs of the population and promote environmentally
            sustainable economic development. In line with the national
            water plan, the national water commission set a new agenda
            to modernize and decentralize the nation's water
            resources by considering all uses and the preservation of
            the environment. The Water Resources Management Project was
            prepared to support these efforts.
